repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - West Beka'a Emergency Water
            Supply Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the West Beka'a
            Emergency Water Supply Project for Lebanon were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the history of performance in key institutional
            areas provides critical insight into likely project
            performance. Improvements in physical infrastructure and
            service delivery were not sufficient to induce a change in
            the culture of not subscribing or not paying. Potential
            subscribers were drawn from households long accustomed to
            poor quality service, creating a mistrust of the service
            provider's announced plans for a consistently high
            quality service. In the case of West Beka'a, the
            simplification of the project design was a double-edged
            sword. On the one hand it allowed for successful development
            of physical infrastructure to meet the needs of an expanding
            population, but on the other hand, underestimated the
            institutional disconnect with the population it serves and
            ultimately its impact on beneficiary access. The delayed
            appointment of a full-time Bekaa Regional Water Authority
            (BRWA) Director General impacted its ability to respond to
            the urgent need for increasing subscription and collection
            levels. Once the leadership position was filled, a community
            response mechanism to address these gaps was put in place,
            albeit late in the project lifecycle. Institutional
            development thus requires an internal champion who is both
            empowered and competent to build consensus around solutions
            that can steer the institution toward success as seen by the
            promising results on the West Beka'a subscription program.

repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - West Beka'a Emergency Water
            Supply Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the West
            Beka'a Emergency Water Supply Project is to improve
            health conditions of the population of the West Bekaa
            through the provision of non-contaminated water in increased
            quantities by completely rehabilitating the area's
            water network. This action plan is likely to have a positive
            impact on the number of subscriptions. The extension to the
            grant closing date by 6 months will thus allow for the works
            contractor to assist the Bekaa Regional Water Authority
            (BRWA) in making the connections to the network, as
            subscriptions increase. The closing date for Lebanon,
            project will be extended from November 20, 2011 until May
            20, 2012. This will be the second extension of the project.

            Emergency Water Supply Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - West Beka'a Emergency Water
            Supply Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the West Beka'a
            Emergency Water Supply Project for Lebanon is to improve
            health conditions of the population of the West Beka'a
            through the provision of non-contaminated water in increased
            quantities by completely rehabilitating the area's
            water network. As per the Government of Lebanon (GOL)
            request, the closing date extension will be for 18 months
            from May 20, 2010 to November 20, 2011 to allow for full
            implementation of the 24-month works contract which started
            in August 2009.

repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Bekaa Water Supply Rehabilitation
            and Modernization Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The major development objective of the
            "Bekaa Water Supply Rehabilitation and Modernization
            Project" is to improve the access of the population to
            satisfactory water supply services. The project area
            encompasses 44 villages with a present population of 203,000
            inhabitants and is projected to reach 335,000 by the year
            2030.   The total water demand of the project area is 28,000
            cubic meters per day and is expected to reach 46,000 cubic
            meters per day by the year 2030. Once operational, most of
            the impacts of the Project will be positive.  The project
            will lead to better services to the population and an
            improved environment as a result of the water supply.  This
            will lead to considerable public health benefits for the
            residents of the area.  In particular it is expected to
            result in a reduction in the incidences of water born
            diseases. Adverse environmental impacts during construction
            might not be negligible yet they are only temporary.
            Typical impacts for pipe laying and construction of water
            headworks are dust, noise, traffic congestion, and
            disturbance to the residents of the area but these are
            expected to be within acceptable limits. On the other hand,
            incidents can arise during operation and could involve
            accidental chlorine emissions, pipe bursts, tank leakages,
            and occupational hazards, all of which can lead to serious
            health risks if not addressed and dealt with in an
            appropriate manner.

docna.cdata!:
Lebanon - Bekaa Water Supply Rehabilitation
            and Modernization Project : environmental assessment

Lebanon - Bekaa Water Supply
